author: Chelsea Duff
title: Eleven-year-old Rachel Bloom wrote an essay called “The Need to Belong,” and our hearts are breaking
text:
Eleven-year-old Rachel Bloom wrote an essay called “The Need to Belong,” and our hearts are breaking At some point in our lives, we’ve all known what it’s like to be left out. That feeling of being excluded stings — and it stays with us. Oprah has etiquette suggestions for when you’re left out , but young Rachel Bloom dealt differently with feeling alienated . 
In 1999, an eleven-year-old Rachel Bloom wrote an essay. That essay was called “The Need To Belong” and it’s absolutely heartbreaking. In it, Rachel bares her sixth-grade soul on a single page of lined paper. Even as a kid, Rachel Bloom was no stranger to depression and anxiety , and reading these emotional words makes us want to reach through the page to give little Rachel a hug. 

Bloom posted the essay on her Instagram as a #ThrowbackThursday, writing, “#tbt to a personal essay I wrote in sixth grade called “The Need to Belong.” This is how it feels to be the weird kid. You want to fit in so badly but you literally don’t know how.”
“This winter vacation, I vowed to myself that I’d try not to be as annoying,” she quoted from the piece. 
She tells the whole story in her essay, and every line pulls at our heartstrings.
A post shared by Rachel Bloom (@racheldoesstuff) on Mar 23, 2017 at 1:27pm PDT 

“I need to belong at school,” Bloom began the essay. “I’m one of those students who has a 3.5 grade average and helps people with their work. I’m also outgoing, and can sometimes be annoying.”
The previous summer, she decided to try and change that, but it wasn’t so simple. “I went out and bought tons of new clothes. I realized that the clothes helped me fit in a little more, until I noticed that my attitude needed to change as well. This winter vacation, I vowed to myself that I’d try to not be as annoying. It’s working so far, I guess. I belong at home. My mom and dad act just like me. We share the same jokes and behaviors. See, one of my major motives in life is to make people laugh. Sometimes I may come off a bit too strongly with the jokes, which passes me off as totally lame and a weirdo. I know I’m not those things, and I dearly wish that some other kids would realize that too… The one place I long to fit in is school. If I completely fit in at school, my life would be a bit more complete.” 
Luckily, little Rachel at least realized she wasn’t alone. 
“I think even the most popular boys + girls at this school even are still striving to belong.” We’re glad Bloom knew that she wasn’t a weirdo or the only one feeling the way. But we still wish we could go back and make things better — and tell her just how many people she would make laugh one day. Judging by the comments on the page, though, it sounds like her teacher was there for her. 
“As we change + grow, so do our friends,” her teacher wrote. “Sounds like you are doing some important growing right now!”
These days, Bloom is accepting herself exactly as she is. And telling fans and followers they can get lost if they don’t like it. Especially when it comes to her Instagram. 
If you hate dog pics and vids you should unfollow me 
A post shared by Rachel Bloom (@racheldoesstuff) on Mar 24, 2017 at 7:36am PDT 
If you’re not here for her dog pics and vids, it’s not her problem. You can be the one to go. And the dog pics and vids have been quite plentiful lately.
Wiley says happy belated #nationalpuppyday from inside the special dog backpack I bought for her 
A post shared by Rachel Bloom (@racheldoesstuff) on Mar 24, 2017 at 4:40am PDT 
Wiley's first time in the snow. 
A post shared by Rachel Bloom (@racheldoesstuff) on Mar 20, 2017 at 9:06am PDT 
A post shared by Rachel Bloom (@racheldoesstuff) on Mar 14, 2017 at 8:42pm PDT 
Personally, we love the dog pics. And we love Bloom. So we’ll be sticking around, watching Crazy Ex-Girlfriend , and feeling like we’ve found the perfect place for us. We fit in just perfectly here.
